segments.text: battalion there.
Actually one time we had a battalion at the Ordnance Depot at Texarkana, Arkansas and one at Fort Polk, Louisiana and our brigade headquarters was at Fort Chaffee.
So I would use our helicopters or air transportation to visit both places, spend a day or two
each week with the other battalions.
We would visit and then the other battalions would be report to active duty some other time at some other place.
Might have been at Fort McCoy, Wisconsin, Camp Perry, Ohio, various places.
We went wherever the Army sent us.
And nearly every year
We would have somebody in the Washington area.
So you went where the Army needed the skills?
Sure.
We might have something to do with choosing our post camper station because we would try to determine once Fifth Army headquarters
would notify us of what the possibilities were.

We would check to see what the suitability of the facilities and the projects available were so that we could confer then with the commanding general of the Army Readiness Region or Fifth Army about the suitability of this.
If there were more than one possibility, well, we would have a chance to exercise some
selectivity based upon the training that would be available.
And also based upon what we considered to be the interest of the troops in going there.
Because of course we were always interested in having them reenlist in the reserves.
trying to use this as a recruiting advantage when recruiting got tough.
What kind of things would you look forward or look for in the interest of the troops?
Well we would look for what sort of support facilities would be available on the post.
Post exchange facilities, service clubs.
Cafeterias.
Theaters.
things for off-duty entertainment of the troops.
And even more important than that, we looked for what was available to support the training projects.
That is, did the post engineer have all the materials we needed for the various kind of construction projects?
Were we able to do dirt work?
vertical construction, exercise, all of the skills, carpenters, electricians, plumbers, everything.
So these men could use the skills that they had.
Absolutely.
Oh yeah.
And so they'd do things that weren't just make work.
Absolutely.
And you know I commanded an artillery battalion and of course when we got through and left was there wasn't anything left behind.
Right.
We were, we had a destruction mission so I liked the engineer
Yeah.
Activities, because when we left, you could see what was done there could be attributed forever to the unit that did the construction.
So they took quite a lot of pride in that.
Yeah.
I would think so.
Let's talk about the growth.
During the 1970s, of course, this is another period in which there is a draft, a very active draft.
And of course, the war in Vietnam.
Did your command, did the numbers of your command grow, or did the waiting lines increase?
Well, the all-volunteer Army time, let's see, I don't remember a draft period in the 70s.
We've registered for the draft right now, but I don't remember.
Drafted until about 62.
Yeah, but you said 70s.
Yeah, I mean 72.
Drafted until about 72, I mean.
And then we get the all-volunteer.
About 73 we get the all-volunteer.
Well, during the draft period, we were in much better position.
And we weren't near as good then as we were in the 50s because the likelihood of actually being conscripted was much lower during that period than it was during the 50s.
So people were much more willing to take a chance, one in a thousand or something that they might be drafted.
And of course with the old volunteer army and denial of our
being able to use the ROTC cadet.
We were restricted on that.
Oh, when did that come about?
I don't remember exactly.
But it was based on a principle that a cadet couldn't draw off two checks from the federal government or something like that.
Anyhow, we got to the point where we couldn't use the ROTC cadets anymore.
Must have been about the mid-1970s.
I don't know when it was.
I think it was earlier than that.
That dried up a major source of outstanding young people.
And during the old Volunteer Army, we've had to devote an untold amount of time to recruiting, and it was just sort of a declining proposition all the time.
And of course, until today, apparently all of the units are substantially understrength, including the active Army units.
Actually, shortly after I left, the very last duty I performed is go to advise the chief staff of the United States Army about recruiting in Army reserves.
They had an intention to take away the recruiting responsibility from the reserves themselves with the support people we had of civilian type, civil service people.
and turn over the recruiting responsibility to the recruiting command.
And I tried as hard as I could to persuade them not to do that, but they did it anyway.
Okay, why did you want, what was at issue here?
Why did you want them not to do that?
Well, we were the best in the 5th Army at recruiting in our particular brigade.
We had dedicated people, civil service type.
And I just didn't figure that anybody else would have as strong an interest in our success as we did ourselves.
And of course it was a point of pride to us that we were the most successful recruiting unit, major unit in the whole Fifth Army.
Which went all the way up to Michigan.
The Fifth Army was just one of three Continental armies, so there were a lot of units in it.
We, of any major command, we had the best
recruiting success.
We worked at it real hard.
And so you didn't want the federal, or you didn't want the Washington people to take over?
Well, they weren't based in Washington, but the recruiting command was based in Illinois.
We were given fairly substantial resources to do this job.
A group of dual service people that were full time employees on a civil service basis, but they also functioned in the Army Reserves in most cases, you see.
And we had recruited some fine people into that.
These people were well led, fairly well supported with resources.
so I just didn't want to lose all the resources, the people, the momentum would build up, sure.
Now let's talk about the numbers.
New York Command, 1971, how many in the 420th, how many men and officers did you have and then when you retired, how many did you have?
Well the authorized strength was some 4,400.
That fluctuated a little bit, but it was around.
4,000 people.
They were located in four states, headquarters here at Bryan.
There was some little change over time.
A petroleum unit was moved out.
We gained some, lost some, but there wasn't any substantial change during any time I was assigned to the brigade.
And authorized strength
Didn't vary much.
But did actual strength vary?
I mean, in 1971 you had approximately 4,400.
How many did you have?
Well, that was what was authorized, and we were full strength then, and yes, our units fluctuated quite a bit.
We did pit one against another, but they ranged in strength from, let's say, 70% to some over 100% strength.
So we see approximately a 30% decline then?
No, no, no, no.
I'm talking about individual units.
Oh, okay.
When I retired, I think that the entire brigade was about 90%, a little over 90% strength.
So it declined from 100%.
Sure.
And actually after the 90th Division was deactivated, it was up well over 100%.
You see with the overstrength that they picked up from the 90th division and it had declined to somewhere in the lower 90s in strength.
Okay, then the end of the draft and the all-volunteer service then didn't seem to have that much of a manpower impact on your command, did it?
Well, it had a strong impact because it took so much of our attention, so much of our resources to maintain recruiting and retention effort.
Oh, I see.
To keep your numbers up.
Yes, to keep the numbers up.
And we had our retention rate on reenlistment
Now I'm wondering about the relations that your reserve unit, engineering unit had with the regular Corps of Engineers.
Can you tell me about that?
Well sure, we of course were commanded by the Army Readiness Region and the Fifth Army,
For technical purposes, we were affiliated directly with the chief engineers, so we were authorized to maintain liaison with the chief engineers.
The chief engineers would have a meeting every year of all of the major commanders of the Army Reserve units.
We're affiliated with the Corps Engineer at Fort Hood.
We were fairly free to establish liaison with engineer units as needed or required.
Did you ever do any work in this area on any of the Corps of Engineer projects like Somerville or anything like that?
We used the Lake Somerville reservoir area sometimes for weekend exercises, but as far as construction projects there, we did not.
There are 19 core reservoirs in this state.
We did have liaison with the Dallas region, let's see, Dallas region, Fort Worth region,
Dallas District Engineers.
This is a construction supervision group.
We established liaison with them and we did some projects for them but not at Fort Somerville.
We drilled some wells.
We have well running detachment and we have drilled some wells for them where they would furnish the materials and we would use our equipment.
And we've done some other
minor construction projects on Corps of Engineers reservoirs.
For instance, Canyon Lake.
We did quite a bit of construction around Canyon Lake when we had units at Camp Willis.
And actually we had some that did their entire two weeks of training right at Canyon
We had a very wide variety of things.
I know one year we were at Fort Chaffee.
We drilled a water well for one of the little towns near Fort Chaffee.
Now during the years that you were in command, there was a great change going on in American society, especially toward women and blacks.
Were there more women and more blacks came into the reserves under your command during
those years?
Well early on during my command we were very successful in recruiting women.
There were certain military occupational specialties that we were authorized to assign them to.
After a year of fairly good success at that we had an about face on policy and we had to
to relieve the women assigned to our combat units.
For instance, our combat battalion in Arkansas had maybe as many as 75 women altogether.
We were required to reassign them to headquarters units and non-combat type units.
So as reservists, you had assigned women to combat units?
Yes.
And what?
What year's release?
Non-combat military occupational specialties in combat units.
Oh, I see.
I see.
OK, so what kind of specialty would they do?
What non-combat specialty would they do in these combat units?
Clerk, supply specialists.
Get the supplies to the mount.
Take care of personnel.
Personnel matters, headquarters things.
Now why were they reassigned?
Well it was policy, a changed policy of the Department of Defense and Department of Army.
And they could not do any of it?
We thought it was related some to the resistance to assignment of, to admission of women to West Point at that time.
It was great, great resistance to that at the time and that's the reason they were keeping them out then
That's what they were using for the primary justification is that women were not suitable for combat.
We thought that was the main thing that caused them to change their policy about allowing these women to be in combat units.
As far as blacks are concerned, that varied quite a lot depending upon where the units were located.
Some of our Louisiana units had a fairly high percentage
of blacks.
And to some extent on where the reserve center was, where our unit was established.
If it was in a neighborhood that was primarily a minority neighborhood blacks, well we'd have a pretty high percentage of blacks in the units.
We never had any problem with meeting our goals on percentage of minorities in units.
of course in our units that were in an area where there was a fairly high percentage of Latin Americans, well we'd have a lot of Latin Americans in the reserve unit.
Now did those numbers increase over the years?
The number of blacks and the number of women?
The number of blacks increased
The women increased early, but then after we were denied the opportunity to assign combat units, it decreased.
That is the number we had decreased.
Any problems with the blacks or women in the reserves?
No problems at all with the women.
Actually, the enlistment requirements were somehow for female and for male.
I believe they had just a little more responsibility and dedication than the Army Preserve soldier.
I was very pleased with the performance of the females in the Army Preserve.
The blacks were very variable.
In our Louisiana unit, a good many of them were category four on their mental tests.
could barely read and write at all.
Some used the reserves as a means of getting into the army.

The reserves could take people with lower mental qualifications than the active army could, but if they got in the reserves and then failed to meet some of their commitments, like attendance at active duty for training, after they missed so many times
the punishment was to put them in the Army.
Really?
For a 45 day period or whatever, and of course that's what they were looking for anyway.
So we resented the fact that too many of them used the reserves as a means of getting around the stricter requirements for a prisoner in the active army.
We did have some problems with the clannishness of the blacks and whites.
Never any race riots or anything like that.
But I would say that the cooperation between blacks and whites varied by geographical location units.
Cooperation was better or worse in what geography?
It was worse in Louisiana than it was in Texas.
Worse in some units in Arkansas.
The higher the percentage of blacks we had, the less likely it would that there'd be close cooperation.
And I'd have to say based upon their background,
leaders in the units would more likely be 80 or 90% whites.
So I'm sure there was some resentment about that.
Though I'd say that we carefully tried to avoid any discrimination on the basis of race, but we did try to pick the best qualified people to be in the leadership roles or for promotion.
due to quite a lot of difference in the background and training that the whites were more likely to be qualified on the basis of education and performance in jobs where education was a factor.
What's your opinion of drafting women?
I've had real good experience with women in the Army Reserve organizations.
I have not had any experience with them under a combat situation.
They have been tested that way.
They have, of course, not surprisingly been found to be somewhat deficient in stamina and strength.
But as far as dedication and courage and performance, I think they're fully up to the men.
I think they tended to play a role, but the ones that I was associated with, of course, were volunteers and they were inclined
I hate to generalize on it 100% because I just haven't had that much experience.
I'm pretty certain that in today's environment in the United States that there will be some sort of draft for women as well as for men.
All of the emphasis on equal rights, that has to be a reflection of that.
Would you agree with that?
I suppose it would.
What about drafting women into combat roles?
I'm not sure.
I have mixed emotions about that.
Of course we saw them perform combat roles in the Russian Army and in some cases in the German Army, so we know darn well they can do it.
But I'd rather see us under tremendous stress before we did that to any great degree.
Not only women, but people my age, too.
We saw those served in the German Army.
We know that in the event of full mobilization that you're not nearly as selective on aid use.
We need to take advantage of the tremendous experience of people that have been in the armed forces in that case.
You made it to the rank of general.
Perhaps you can give me some ideas on this.
How does one get ahead in the military?
Is it the same or similar as getting ahead in civilian life, or are there differences?
Oh, I think it's the same characteristics that you would look for in a civilian.
In your career, did you think that
Getting ahead depended on your performance or help from others?
Both.
Your own performance and certainly nobody gets extremely high rank in either military or civilian without a lot of help from others.
There has to be, I presume,
In any case, some element of luck, but it takes a lot of preparation.
Which is more important?
Preparation.
I forgot who it was that said, I found that the harder I work, the luckier I am.
That's a good one.
I like that.
That's a good one.
Would you have considered yourself ambitious?
Sure.
Still ain't.
In what way?
Well, I like to satisfy myself with whatever I might undertake to do.
Can be performed a little above the expectations of those to whom I report.
That's a matter of self-satisfaction, I guess.
Sure.
Speaking of your command, again, and your entire military career, and every man's life who's spent a number of years, three decades, doing something, there's always accomplishments.
There's also always shortcomings.
Not probably failures, but things that you wanted to do that for some reason you just couldn't do.
Would you discuss your accomplishments and your shortcomings?

Well, in accomplishments, I have always gotten a tremendous amount of satisfaction out of the progress and recognition of those for whom I am responsible, whether on the civilian side or the military side.
So I got a real ego boost when those that I might have had something to do with training have responsibility for to excel and are recognized for it.
I'm proud of the performance of the military units to which I was assigned.
I think without exception they were above average to exceptional units.
And that gave me a lot of satisfaction.
And of course the capabilities of units are measured in fairly
in what you would say objective ways by the Army.
We tested regularly and we were able to meet the test, so I like that.
I suppose for shortcomings, one of the things I hoped to do was to earn
for the 420th Engineer Brigade, such high recognition that the Department of Army would designate it as an engineer command, which would qualify for the rank of Major General, Brigadier General.
And I failed in that.
Johanna were before me and I tried to
perform in such a way that of the four major engineer units in the United States, two were brigades and two were commands.
We were never able to arrest one of those commands away from the headquarters in Mississippi or headquarters in Chicago, Illinois.
Of course, we consoled ourselves that that was politics rather than merit.
I don't know, anyhow we weren't able to get the job done and that was a disappointment to me.
Most of the other disappointments I had as it turned out in the military proved to be just good luck.
I was disappointed not to be promoted to lieutenant colonel before 1953.
If I had been, I would have
Probably gone to Colonel earlier and served my time in grade and then relieved from active duty before I had a chance to get a star.
There were two or three instances like that where what at the time looked like a disadvantage proved later to be an advantage.
I'd say other than that, one of my great disappointments was getting wounded in a way that there was really not any excuse for, so I failed to wind up the entire combat mission in Europe.
